title: Strategic Games
description: Games that surface priorities, reveal trade-offs, and help teams make difficult decisions together
philosophy: Strategic thinking becomes clearer through play. Games create safe spaces to explore trade-offs without the weight of immediate consequences.

games.name: Dilemma Duel
games.purpose: Surface ethical values and decision-making frameworks through scenario debates

team_size_adaptations.small: Whole group debates each dilemma together
team_size_adaptations.medium: Split into two teams per dilemma, structured debate format
team_size_adaptations.large: Multiple parallel debates, then synthesis of reasoning patterns

rules.instructions: AI presents a dilemma with two defensible choices. Both options have merits. Read the scenario carefully.
rules.facilitator_notes: Choose dilemmas relevant to project domain. Neither option should be obviously right.

rules.instructions: Team splits into two camps based on initial gut reaction. If uneven, some volunteers switch to balance.
rules.facilitator_notes: Encourage people to argue positions they might not personally hold - builds empathy.

rules.instructions: Each side prepares their best arguments. Focus on values and principles, not just outcomes.
rules.facilitator_notes: Push for 'because we believe...' statements, not just 'because it works better'

rules.instructions: Structured debate: Side A presents (2 min), Side B responds (2 min), Side B presents (2 min), Side A responds (2 min), open discussion (2 min).
rules.facilitator_notes: Enforce time limits strictly. Encourage steel-manning the other side.

rules.instructions: What values were revealed on each side? What principle could honor both concerns?
rules.facilitator_notes: This is the gold. The debate reveals values; the extraction captures them.

prompts: This dilemma has no perfect answer. What values are in tension here?
If you had to explain your choice to someone who disagrees, what would you say?
What would you need to believe for the other side to be right?
What's the strongest argument against your position?
ai_facilitation.synthesis_instructions: Capture the core values on each side. Identify potential synthesis positions. Note which arguments changed minds. Document the team's ethical reasoning patterns.
follow_up_questions: What did the other side say that made you think?
Is there a third option that honors both values?
How might this dilemma appear in our actual project?
What principle should guide similar decisions in the future?

sample_dilemmas.title: Speed vs. Security
sample_dilemmas.scenario: You discover a critical bug that affects 10% of users. You can ship a quick fix in 2 hours (some risk of new bugs) or a thorough fix in 2 weeks (users suffer longer but fix is bulletproof).
sample_dilemmas.option_b: Take time for the thorough fix

sample_dilemmas.title: Transparency vs. Privacy
sample_dilemmas.scenario: Your AI system makes decisions that affect users. Full transparency would help users understand decisions but might expose proprietary logic. Opacity protects IP but feels manipulative.
sample_dilemmas.option_a: Full transparency about how decisions are made

sample_dilemmas.title: User Request vs. User Wellbeing
sample_dilemmas.scenario: Users are requesting a feature that gives them more control, but your data suggests the feature often leads to worse outcomes for them. They want autonomy; you have information they don't.
sample_dilemmas.option_a: Give users the control they're asking for
sample_dilemmas.option_b: Protect users from their own potentially harmful choices

outputs: Potential ethical boundaries for the project
success_indicators: Clear values emerge from the debates

variations.name: Devil's Advocate Rotation
variations.description: Everyone must argue for 1 minute against their actual position
variations.when_to_use: When the team tends toward groupthink

variations.name: Stakeholder Lens
variations.description: Debate from the perspective of different stakeholders identified in Stakeholder Safari
variations.when_to_use: After completing Stakeholder Safari, to connect ethics to real people

games.connection_to_axiom_zero: Debating difficult dilemmas with respect builds deep trust. Love requires the courage to explore hard questions together.

games.name: Value Auction
games.purpose: Reveal true priorities through competitive bidding on limited resources

team_size_adaptations.small: Individual bidding, each person gets points
team_size_adaptations.medium: Team bidding (2-3 teams), forces internal prioritization first
team_size_adaptations.large: Representative bidders for stakeholder groups, others coach

materials: Bidding tokens or points (100 per participant/team)

rules.instructions: Each participant/team receives 100 points. Values will be auctioned. You cannot get more points. Choose wisely.
rules.facilitator_notes: The scarcity is essential. Don't give more points than planned.

rules.instructions: Review all values up for auction. Discuss what each means. No bidding strategy discussion yet.
rules.facilitator_notes: Ensure everyone understands each value. Clarify but don't influence.

rules.instructions: Privately decide your top priorities. How will you allocate your 100 points?
rules.facilitator_notes: This private reflection is crucial. Don't let teams coordinate strategy.

rules.instructions: Each value is auctioned. Highest bidder wins. Winner must explain why this value was worth the price.
rules.facilitator_notes: Move briskly. Allow brief bidding wars. Celebrate bold bids.

rules.instructions: What values sold high? What was surprisingly cheap? What does this reveal about our priorities?
rules.facilitator_notes: Note: both winning values AND bidding behavior are data points.

prompts: Current bid is [X] points. Going once... anyone willing to invest more in [value]?
You spent [X] points on [value]. What would you sacrifice to protect this in your project?
This value went for only [X] points. Does that surprise anyone?
Who had to let a value go that they really wanted? What was that like?
ai_facilitation.synthesis_instructions: Rank values by final price paid. Identify surprising gaps between stated and revealed preferences. Note which values had bidding wars (shared priority) vs. easy wins (unique priority). Calculate 'priority coefficient' = price paid / average price.
follow_up_questions: What do our bids reveal about our true priorities?
Which values did we claim to care about but didn't bid on?
Where did our priorities align? Where did they diverge?
How should these priorities influence our technical decisions?

success_indicators: Some participants feel the scarcity tension

variations.name: Negative Auction
variations.description: Auction off 'anti-values' or risks. What would you pay to avoid? (e.g., technical debt, scope creep)
variations.when_to_use: When team needs to confront risks, not just celebrate values

variations.name: Stakeholder Budget
variations.description: Each bidder represents a stakeholder. Bid as that stakeholder would.
variations.when_to_use: After Stakeholder Safari, to test stakeholder priority alignment

games.connection_to_axiom_zero: Scarcity reveals truth. By trusting each other with our real priorities, we build a foundation of honesty. Love guides us to prioritize what truly matters for human flourishing.

games.name: Trade-Off Tetris
games.purpose: Visualize and navigate competing constraints through spatial arrangement

team_size_adaptations.medium: Parallel boards by sub-team, then merge attempts

materials: Large canvas (physical or digital - Miro, FigJam)
Different colors for different constraint types

rules.instructions: List all constraints: time, budget, team size, technical limitations, dependencies, quality requirements, stakeholder demands. Size blocks by relative weight.
rules.facilitator_notes: Get specific. 'Limited time' -> 'Must ship by March 1' -> block sized for 10 weeks.

rules.instructions: Draw the container: this represents your total capacity. All blocks must fit inside.
rules.facilitator_notes: Container size should be realistic - maybe 70% of what blocks add up to.

rules.instructions: Try to fit all blocks into the container. Arrange and rearrange. What fits? What has to be smaller? What can't fit at all?
rules.facilitator_notes: Let the struggle happen. Don't suggest solutions yet.

rules.instructions: Some blocks won't fit. What can we shrink? What can we remove? What's non-negotiable?
rules.facilitator_notes: This is where real trade-offs are made. Push for specificity.

rules.instructions: Lock in a configuration that fits. Document what was traded off and why.
rules.facilitator_notes: Take a photo/screenshot. This becomes a reference artifact.

prompts: If you could magically shrink one block, which would it be? What would you lose?
This block doesn't fit. What would need to change for it to fit?
You've removed [X]. What's the consequence of that trade-off?
Is there a block you're treating as non-negotiable that might actually have flexibility?
ai_facilitation.synthesis_instructions: Document final configuration. List all blocks that were removed or shrunk. Record the rationale for each trade-off. Identify which constraints were treated as truly fixed vs. negotiable.
follow_up_questions: What trade-off was hardest to make?
What assumption about the container size should we question?
Are there creative ways to make blocks smaller without losing value?
What's the biggest risk in our final configuration?

variations.name: Time-Lapse Tetris
variations.description: Redo the exercise for different time horizons (MVP, v1.0, v2.0). See how blocks change.
variations.when_to_use: When there's a phased roadmap or unclear scope

variations.name: Stakeholder Tetris
variations.description: Each stakeholder group creates their own configuration. Compare and reconcile.
variations.when_to_use: When stakeholder alignment is a key challenge

games.connection_to_axiom_zero: Making trade-offs together builds trust - we share the weight of difficult decisions. Love means accepting constraints to serve what matters most.
